metadata.description: New Testament Manuscript Database for Timeline Visualization
metadata.notes: Dates are paleographic estimates. Coordinates represent discovery/origin locations where known, otherwise current repository locations.

oxyrhynchus.name: Oxyrhynchus
oxyrhynchus.description: Ancient Egyptian city, major source of NT papyri discoveries

alexandria.name: Alexandria
alexandria.description: Center of Alexandrian text-type, major early Christian scholarly center

fayum.name: Fayum
fayum.description: Egyptian oasis region, source of many papyri

antioch.name: Antioch
antioch.description: Early center of Christianity, origin of Antiochene text

jerusalem.name: Jerusalem
jerusalem.description: Origin point of Christianity and earliest manuscripts

manuscripts.name: Rylands Library Papyrus P52
manuscripts.significance: Earliest known New Testament manuscript fragment
manuscripts.notes: Discovered in 1920 by Bernard Grenfell on the Egyptian market. Front contains John 18:31-33, back contains 18:37-38.

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 90
manuscripts.significance: One of the earliest witnesses to the Gospel of John

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 104
manuscripts.significance: One of the earliest witnesses to the Gospel of Matthew

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 98
manuscripts.significance: Earliest manuscript of Revelation
manuscripts.notes: Institut Français d'Archéologie Orientale, P. IFAO inv. 237b

manuscripts.name: Chester Beatty Papyrus II
manuscripts.contents: Romans, Hebrews, 1-2 Corinthians, Ephesians, Galatians, Philippians, Colossians, 1 Thessalonians
manuscripts.significance: Earliest substantial witness to Paul's letters; oldest manuscript of Hebrews
manuscripts.notes: 86 leaves survive of original 104. Missing 2 Thessalonians, Philemon, and Pastorals. 30 leaves at University of Michigan.

manuscripts.name: Papyrus Bodmer II
manuscripts.significance: Most complete early papyrus of John's Gospel
manuscripts.notes: Does not contain the pericope adulterae (John 7:53-8:11)

manuscripts.name: Papyrus Bodmer XIV-XV
manuscripts.significance: Third most important NT manuscript after Vaticanus and Sinaiticus; exceptional agreement with Codex Vaticanus

manuscripts.name: Chester Beatty Papyrus I
manuscripts.significance: Oldest manuscript of Mark's Gospel; earliest witness to Acts
manuscripts.notes: 30 leaves of original ~220 survive. One leaf in Vienna.

manuscripts.name: Chester Beatty Papyrus III
manuscripts.significance: Oldest substantial manuscript of Revelation

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 20
manuscripts.significance: Earliest manuscript of the Epistle of James

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 1
manuscripts.significance: First NT papyrus discovered at Oxyrhynchus (1896-97)
manuscripts.notes: Discovered by Grenfell and Hunt on second day of excavation

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 4
manuscripts.notes: May be from the same codex as P64 and P67

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 13
manuscripts.significance: Important early witness to Hebrews
manuscripts.notes: P. Oxy. 657. Extremely close textual agreement with P46, Codex Vaticanus, and Sahidic Coptic

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 32
manuscripts.significance: Earliest witness to the Pastoral Epistles

manuscripts.name: Magdalen Papyrus
manuscripts.significance: One of the earliest Matthew manuscripts
manuscripts.notes: May be from the same codex as P4 and P67

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 67
manuscripts.notes: Almost certainly from the same codex as P4 and P64

manuscripts.name: Papyrus Bodmer VII-VIII
manuscripts.significance: Oldest complete text of Jude, 1 Peter, and 2 Peter
manuscripts.notes: Also contains Nativity of Mary, Odes of Solomon, and other texts

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 87
manuscripts.significance: Earliest witness to Philemon besides P46

manuscripts.name: Codex Sinaiticus
manuscripts.contents: Complete New Testament (plus Barnabas and Shepherd of Hermas)
manuscripts.significance: Oldest complete New Testament manuscript; one of the four great uncial codices
manuscripts.notes: Discovered by Tischendorf at St. Catherine's Monastery, Sinai (1844-1859). Portions also held in Leipzig, St. Petersburg, and St. Catherine's.

manuscripts.name: Codex Vaticanus
manuscripts.contents: Most of Old Testament and New Testament (lacks Hebrews 9:14-end, 1-2 Timothy, Titus, Philemon, Revelation)
manuscripts.significance: Considered the most accurate and trustworthy early manuscript; one of the four great uncial codices
manuscripts.notes: In Vatican Library since before 1475. Possibly one of 50 Bibles commissioned by Constantine.

manuscripts.name: Codex Alexandrinus
manuscripts.contents: Nearly complete Bible (lacks Matthew 1-25:6, John 6:50-8:52, 2 Corinthians 4:13-12:6)
manuscripts.significance: One of the four great uncial codices; valuable witness to Revelation
manuscripts.notes: Presented to King Charles I in 1627. Possibly originated in Alexandria, Egypt.

manuscripts.name: Codex Ephraemi Rescriptus
manuscripts.significance: One of the four great uncial codices; most important palimpsest
manuscripts.notes: Palimpsest - 12th century overwriting of sermons of Ephraem Syrus on 5th century biblical text

manuscripts.name: Codex Bezae Cantabrigiensis
manuscripts.significance: Principal witness to the Western text-type
manuscripts.notes: Greek and Latin on facing pages. Given to Cambridge by Theodore Beza in 1581.

manuscripts.name: Codex Washingtonianus
manuscripts.significance: Third oldest Greek manuscript of the Gospels; contains 'Freer Logion'
manuscripts.notes: Purchased from Egypt in 1906. Now at Smithsonian's Freer Gallery of Art, Washington DC.

manuscripts.name: Uncial 0171
manuscripts.significance: One of the earliest parchment manuscripts

manuscripts.name: Uncial 0189
manuscripts.significance: One of the earliest parchment manuscripts of Acts

manuscripts.name: Uncial 0220
manuscripts.significance: One of the earliest parchment manuscripts of Romans

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 2
manuscripts.notes: Lectionary fragment. Bilingual Greek and Coptic

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 11
manuscripts.significance: First biblical papyrus discovered (Tischendorf, 1862); first cited in a critical apparatus

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 12
manuscripts.notes: May have been a writing exercise or amulet

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 48
manuscripts.notes: Important Western text witness for Acts

manuscripts.name: Papyrus Bodmer XVII
manuscripts.significance: Most extensive papyrus of Acts and Catholic Epistles
manuscripts.notes: Purchased with Bodmer collection. Contains nearly complete text of Acts and all Catholic Epistles.

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 108
manuscripts.notes: P. Oxy. 4447. One of the earliest witnesses to John

manuscripts.name: Papyrus 115
manuscripts.significance: Contains 666 as the number of the beast, written as 616
manuscripts.notes: P. Oxy. 4499. Important witness to Revelation

manuscripts.name: Codex Laudianus
manuscripts.significance: Important witness to Acts
manuscripts.notes: Used by Bede for his commentary on Acts

manuscripts.name: Codex Boernerianus
manuscripts.notes: Contains famous Irish poem in the margin

manuscripts.name: Codex Coislinianus
manuscripts.significance: Important Alexandrian witness to Pauline Epistles

manuscripts.name: Codex Freerianus
manuscripts.notes: Part of Freer collection with Codex Washingtonianus

manuscripts.name: Codex Regius
manuscripts.significance: Important Alexandrian witness. Contains both endings of Mark

manuscripts.name: Codex Koridethi
manuscripts.significance: Important witness to Caesarean text-type

manuscripts.name: Codex Zacynthius
manuscripts.significance: Oldest known New Testament manuscript with marginal commentary

manuscripts.name: Codex Athous Laurensis
manuscripts.notes: Mixed text in Gospels; Alexandrian in Acts and Catholic Epistles

manuscripts.name: Codex Athous Laurensis
manuscripts.significance: Important witness to Revelation

manuscripts.name: Uncial 0162
manuscripts.notes: P. Oxy. 847. One of earliest parchment manuscripts

manuscripts.name: Diatessaron Fragment
manuscripts.significance: Earliest fragment of Tatian's Diatessaron (Gospel harmony)

timelineEvents.significance: James or Galatians traditionally dated earliest
Shift of Christianity away from Jerusalem
Final book of New Testament composed
Major early collections of NT books
Transition from uncial to minuscule writing
Greek scholars flee west with manuscripts

spreadPatterns.notes: Gospels and letters written and initially copied in major Christian centers
Egypt becomes major center; most surviving early papyri from this region due to climate
Distinct text-types develop: Alexandrian, Caesarean, Western
Constantine's patronage; great uncial codices produced
Byzantine text-type becomes standard in Greek-speaking world
